entry.title: SAP ERP (ECC 6.0 on RISE) Integration with DRC Peppol Exchange ‚Äì Questions for Belgium Setup
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

This is my first time implementing the integration between SAP ERP and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) for Peppol Exchange, following SAP‚Äôs official documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-edition/sap-document-and-reporting-compliance-cloud-edition/integrating-peppol-exchange-with-sap-erp?locale=en-US

However, I find the documentation quite high-level ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt go deep enough into the technical aspects, and I‚Äôm a bit confused about certain configuration points.

Context

I‚Äôm currently implementing the integration between SAP ERP ECC 6.0 (SAP RISE) and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) ‚Äì Peppol Exchange for Belgium (BE).

So far, all the main configuration tasks have been completed:

  • The eDocument Cockpit is fully configured and working correctly in SAP ECC.

  • SAP DRC Peppol Exchange is deployed on SAP BTP (region: Frankfurt).

  • The ERP system is hosted on SAP RISE (region: Virginia).

  • The Cloud Connector is configured and connected to the corresponding BTP subaccount.

  • The Service Binding and Destination (DRC_PEPPOL) were successfully created in BTP.

  • A communication user with all necessary authorizations (SAP_BC_WEBSERVICE_SERVICE_USER, EDO_*, etc.) has been created.

  • The service endpoint in SOAMANAGER has been correctly configured and exposed according to SAP‚Äôs documentation at the following path:
    /sap/bc/srt/rfc/sap/dcppushservice/<xxx>/dcppushservice/pushrequest.

Despite all this, the connection between the ERP and the DRC Cloud Peppol service still cannot be established.
Ping tests return errors such as NIEHOST_UNKNOWN, NIECONN_REFUSED, or ‚ÄúService Unreachable.‚Äù

At this point, I‚Äôm not sure whether the issue is related to:

  • Certificate or trust configuration between ERP and BTP,

  • A network limitation due to the cross-region setup (RISE Virginia ‚Üî BTP Frankfurt),

  • Or something missing in the Peppol participant configuration within the DRC instance.

Additionally, I‚Äôm unsure whether I should ask the client to explicitly allow outbound communication from the DRC Cloud service binding (created in BTP) through SAP‚Äôs internal firewall so that the ERP system can reach the endpoint.
If so, I would appreciate guidance on how this should be done ‚Äî whether it should be managed directly in BTP Cockpit, via a SAP support ticket, or if it is enabled automatically once the binding is created.

Finally, the client assumes that XML ‚Üî UBL transformations must be handled via SAP Integration Suite (CPI), but based on my understanding, the standard SAP DRC solution should already manage these conversions internally.

1 Connection between RISE (Virginia) and BTP (Frankfurt)

Given that the ERP (RISE) and BTP environments are hosted in different regions, do I need to configure an additional SAP Cloud Connector or any special setup to enable secure communication between the two?
Or is the standard connection through the Service Binding and Destination configuration sufficient for DRC Cloud to reach the on-premise ERP?

2 eDocument Format and UBL/BIS 3.0 Transformation

According to SAP‚Äôs documentation, Peppol requires UBL BIS 3.0-compliant documents.
My main questions are:

  • Does the standard DRC solution automatically handle the XML ‚Üí UBL BIS 3.0 transformation when sending eDocuments from SAP ERP to Peppol?

  • Conversely, when receiving documents from Peppol, does DRC automatically convert UBL BIS ‚Üí XML so that it can be consumed by SAP ERP?

  • If these transformations are not handled natively, what‚Äôs the recommended approach to implement them?
    Specifically, how can I connect SAP DRC Cloud with SAP Integration Suite (iFlow) to intercept and transform the payload (UBL/XML) before it reaches the ERP?
    (I would really appreciate if anyone has implemented a similar setup or could share a best-practice example.)

I would also appreciate any insights on special settings that should be considered in the eDocument Cockpit for sending and/or receiving documents.

3. RISE and ECC Connectivity Considerations

The client refers to their system as SAP RISE, but technically the backend is SAP ECC 6.0.
Are there any official SAP guidelines or technical notes describing the recommended configuration for this hybrid scenario (RISE + DRC Cloud) ‚Äî especially regarding trust setup, certificates, or communication channels?
The existing SAP documentation seems too generic, so any deeper or experience-based guidance would be very helpful.

Thank you in advance for your help and insights!
Any detailed documentation, SAP Notes, or examples from similar Belgium Peppol implementations would be highly appreciated.

entry.title: BADI_EDOC_TR_INVOICE_CHANGE : how to map a header text to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in the XML file
entry.content:
Dear All,

Requirement : in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, put the header text of a Billing Document in the XML document

I'm implementing the BADI_EDOC_TR_INVOICE_CHANGE to fulfill this requirement.

In the documentation of this BAdI Definition, there is the following paragraph :

"

To map a specific header text of source documents to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in XML files, you can proceed as follows:

  1. Create a custom field in the Custom Fields and Logic app. Use the Sales: Billing Document business context.

You map a specific header text of source documents to this custom field.

  1. In your BAdI implementation, you map the custom field to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in XML files.

"

I know how to create a Custom Field, but how can "You map a specific header text of source documents to this custom field." ?

The Header Text of a Billing Document is not accessible in a BAdI implementation :

  • Option 1 : CDS :  I_BillingDocumentTextTP : the field "Long Text" is not populated
  • Option 2 : EML : fails, with the error message : Statement "READ ENTITIES" is not allowed with this status
  • Option 3 : API : API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV : fails with Calling "GET_HTTP_REQUEST" "violates transactional contract "FUNCTIONAL"

Many thanks for sharing your ideas.

Kind Regards

Hans

entry.title: My Real-World Guide to SAP Document & Reporting Compliance (DRC Series)
entry.content:
As someone who has worked extensively with SAP Document & Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC) across multiple countries and industries, I‚Äôve seen first-hand how rapidly tax regulations are evolving. Government authorities everywhere are shifting from post-factum tax reporting to real-time Continuous Transaction Controls (CTC).

And this shift is not subtle‚Äîit's massive.

Over the past few years, I‚Äôve helped organizations implement DRC for e-invoicing, SAF-T, e-transport documents, VAT/GST reporting, and more. We have even developed our own SAP DRC extensions and IP to tackle local nuances where standard functionality needed enhancements.

This blog is my attempt to bring together everything I‚Äôve learned so far‚Äîfrom basics to advanced concepts‚Äîin one place.

If you‚Äôre looking to truly understand SAP DRC‚Äîwhat it does, how it works, why it‚Äôs needed, and how it fits into SAP architecture‚Äîthis blog will guide you end-to-end.

1. What is SAP DRC? (From My Experience)

From working on multiple implementations, I‚Äôve learned that SAP DRC is more than a tool‚Äîit's a framework.

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC) acts as the central backbone for:

  • Electronic invoicing
  • Real-time tax reporting (CTC)
  • Periodic statutory reporting
  • SAF-T and digital audit files
  • Digital signatures
  • Legal archiving
  • Automated interactions with government portals

The biggest value I‚Äôve seen in real projects is that DRC reduces manual tax compliance work by 80‚Äì90% and drastically cuts dependency on local middleware.

2. Why Do Companies Need SAP DRC?

(What I‚Äôve Learned Implementing It Across Countries)

Almost every client I‚Äôve worked with is facing the same challenge:
Governments are moving toward real-time digital compliance.

Here‚Äôs the pattern I observed:

Region

Compliance Type

My Client Examples

France, Poland, Portugal

Mexico CFDI, Brazil NFe, Chile DTE

Middle East

KSA ZATCA, UAE

APAC

India IRN/QR

The risks companies face if they don‚Äôt comply are real:

‚ùåRejected invoices
‚ùåShipment block
‚ùåDelayed payments
‚ùåRegulatory penalties
‚ùåAudit red flags

In several implementations, I‚Äôve seen companies who initially relied on manual uploads or local middleware‚Äî
they inevitably had to switch to SAP DRC once volumes increased or rules tightened.

SAP DRC makes sure your SAP system speaks the legal language of your government portal.

3. SAP DRC Architecture ‚Äî Explained From Practical Experience

When you work on DRC projects, this architecture becomes second nature.
Here‚Äôs the clearest way I explain it to clients:

 

In most projects, this means:

  • SAP S/4HANA generates the data
  • Document Compliance formats it
  • DRC Cloud and M2G manage API communication
  • Government returns status

I‚Äôve found this architecture extremely robust and scalable.

4. Key Components of SAP DRC (Based on Hands-On Work)

4.1 Document Processing (E-Invoicing)

This is where magic happens.

In our implementations, Document Compliance handled:

  • Structured XML/JSON generation
  • Mapping to country formats (ZATCA, IRN, CFDI, UBL, SDI, NFe)
  • Digital signatures
  • QR code generation
  • API submission
  • Government responses (success/error, UUID/IRN)
  • Legal archiving
  • Customer PDF + XML distribution

We've even built custom mapping logic and country add-ons as IP where clients needed country-specific non-standard fields.

4.2 Statutory Reporting

I‚Äôve used this extensively for:

  • VAT/GST returns
  • SAF-T files
  • E-transport documents
  • Withholding tax reports
  • Intrastat

ACR reports are extremely powerful for drill-down.

4.3 Machine-to-Government (M2G)

This is the most underrated part.

It ensures:

  • Secure API communication
  • Token & certificate lifecycle
  • Encryption
  • Response validation

We‚Äôve built reusable M2G wrappers as IP to simplify local government connections.

4.4 ACR (Advanced Compliance Reporting)

ACR allows:

  • Real-time dashboards
  • Pre-built country templates
  • Validations
  • Extensibility (BAdIs & custom logic)

We‚Äôve created custom ACR variants where the legal format or reporting rules weren‚Äôt standard.

5. How SAP DRC Works (Real End-to-End Flow I‚Äôve Implemented)

Step 1: Business Transaction

Customer invoice created in S/4HANA.

Step 2: Document Extraction

DRC picks the invoice automatically‚Äîno user involvement.

Step 3: Mapping & XML/JSON Generation

Step 4: Digital Signing & QR Code (where applicable)

Step 5: Submission to Government Portal

Step 6: Receive Govt Response

I‚Äôve seen everything here‚Äîsuccess, rejections, signature mismatches, schema errors.

Step 7: Archive & Distribution

Final legal XML + PDF sent to customer.

This flow is consistent across countries.

These came in especially handy in KSA, Brazil, and EU implementations.
